title-group.article-title: Parenting of children with Down syndrome compared to fragile X syndrome

contrib.aff: University of Wisconsin-Madison, Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders, Goodnight Hall, 1975 Willow Drive, Madison, WI 53706
University of Kansas, 212 Youngberg Hall, 2385 Irving Hill Road, Lawrence, KS 66045, sfwarren@ku.edu

abstract.p: Children with Down syndrome (DS) and fragile X syndrome (FXS) struggle with language development. Parenting variables, such as responsiveness to children’s communication attempts (Maternal Responsivity), and techniques used to support and teach appropriate behaviour (Behaviour Management) are known to have a significant impact on early child development. We examined these two aspects of parenting style via coded, videotaped parent-child interactions in two groups of participants matched on child age (2–5 years) and child expressive language level: mothers of children with DS and mothers of children with FXS. The mothers differed in their use of gestures and redirecting the child’s attention. Overall, mothers in both groups of children appeared to adapt appropriately to their children’s developmental needs.
